message:
We feel extremely sorrowful to inform the demise of Dr. Joydeep Bhattacharya. He drowned trying to save his four-year old child in Kharagpur's Gholgeria area. This truly is a loss to the nation. Dr. Bhattacharya was working in areas like water waves, wave-structure interaction and wave energy devices. He completed his Ph.D. from IIT KGP itself in the year 2008. The Scholars' Avenue extends grievances to the family of Dr. Bhattacharya.

http://www.thestatesman.c...

"It was started as an attempt to create an avenue to meet interesting people doing their own interesting thing and formed a place where people could meet with their own pet projects and help each other. Since then, it has grown to over 3000 articles with contributions by hundreds of KGPians, and more than 500 unique users visiting every day..."
Don't know what we're talking about? Here's your guide to MetaKGP.

In a news that comes as an utter shock to the entire KGP community, Prof. Joydip Bhattacharjee (Ocean Engg and Naval Architecture) is sadly no more among us. He got drowned in a large water filled ditch today while trying to rescue his 4-year-old child who had fallen into the waterbody near the campus. Local people took him and his son out of the water and took them to the hospital where he was declared brought dead while his son has been released after first aid. He had gone out for a ride with his son and daughter to Kharagpur's Gholgeria where the accident happened. According to witnesses, the son accidentally fell into the water and Dr. Bhattacharya jumped in to save him.

Entire KGP community mourns the untimely loss of such a talented and beloved professor. All of our prayers are extended to his family and we hope that our prayers will give them the strength to bear this huge loss.

Source: http://www.business-stand...

message: Khoj'17 - the annual treasure hunt event exclusively for freshers, was organized successfully in the evening yesterday by Azad Hall of Residence. In this campus wide event that was mainly about enjoyment, winning prizes, cycling long distances, getting to know the batch-mates and the serene campus - all while cracking clues after clues and searching for the right codes! Initially, it was the rain which threatened to play spoilsport but with time, the weather got better and better. About 170 teams participated with great zeal and enthusiasm along with the tinge of smile and excitement that was visible on their faces. The theme of the event was Video Games of the 90's and it surely gave freshers the moment to go back to that era and live their dream again!

Hello!

GE is excited to invite you for GE Industrial Internet of Things hackathon - a private forum to encourage and recognize cool ideas that can revolutionize the IIoT. GE has bet big on the Industrial Internet — the convergence of industrial machines, data, and the Internet. We have installed sensors on gas turbines, jet engines, and other machines; connected them to the cloud; and are analyzing the resulting flow of data with an end goal to identify ways to improve machine productivity and reliability. Do you think you have the next BIG IDEA that will help us achieve our goals? Don your innovative hats and register to participate in the Hackathon! We are looking for talented developers who can build innovative solutions around IIoT, Smart City, Smart Machines, Healthcare. This hackathon is open to pre-final and final year engineering students of a select list of college (participating colleges), irrespective of the branch/ stream. Participate in this inter-collegiate hackathon and flaunt your innovative ideas!

Important dates:

Phase 1 (Idea phase) ends on 27th Aug
Phase 2 (Hackathon phase) shortlisted teams will build their application between 1st-24th Sep
Prizes:

Winning team stands a chance to win INR 1,00,000 worth gift cards and the top 3 teams stand a chance to win INR 50,000 gift cards
In addition, Top Teams stand a chance to work or Intern with GE Digital!
Happy Ideation!

For more updates visit the link: https://www.hackerearth.c...

The HRD Ministry has decided to put the plans of introducing a common engineering entrance exam from next year on hold. Earlier, the All India Council of Technical Education (AICTE) had announced in March that a national-level common entrance examination for engineering colleges would be conducted from the next academic year in 2018. However, the idea has not been completely discarded. Apart from JEE, a number of states conduct their own tests where as several private colleges also conduct their own entrance examinations.

The entrance examination for the prestigious Indian Institutes of Technology (IITs) i.e., JEE Advanced will go completely online from 2018. Joint Admission Board (JAB), which is the policymaking body on IIT admissions, took this decision in a meeting on 20th August.
IIT Madras director and JAB 2017 chairman Prof. Bhaskar Ramamurthi said in a statement, “It has been decided that the JEE (Advanced) will be conducted in online mode from 2018 onwards. Further information regarding the examination will be provided by the JAB in due course.”
The HRD ministry had earlier introduced the option of taking the JEE Mains online. However, out of 13 lakh students who took the JEE Mains this year, less than 10% of them opted for online mode.

Source: http://economictimes.indi...

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 2 new photos.
message:
Anthill Creations, founded by five IIT Kharagpur alumni Nancy Charaya(ex-Chief Editor, Awaaz), Pooja Rai, Nupur Agrawal, Souradeep Paul and Vishesh Gupta (all 2015 - B.Arch.), is one of the eight early-stage non-profit startups selected for an 18-month incubation program by the NS Raghavan Centre for Entrepreneurial Learning (NSRCEL) at the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Bangalore. The founders will also receive fellowship support of 18 lakh.
This is part of India's first-ever, non-profit startup incubator supported by the Michael and Susan Dell Foundation. The selected organizations are tackling some of the toughest challenges in education and skills among poor communities around the country.
Anthill Creations aims to build sustainable playscapes for children by using recyclable materials. The idea of Anthill Creations is to create the world where communities come together and active play becomes affordable and accessible to all. It works towards lighter, quicker and cheaper transformation of dead zones into interactive and sustainable playscapes from scrap tyres and recycled material by mobilizing the communities. Recycling non-biodegradable material like tyres, therefore, would not just help safeguard the environment but be cost effective as a building material too.
“Traditionally, mass produced recreational equipment for building a playground would cost a very high price, but since we are using material that is considered trash by some, we have been successful in setting up playgrounds for very cheap cost,” Souradeep had said in an interview.

Anthill Creations, founded by five IIT Kharagpur alumni Nancy Charaya, Pooja Rai, Nupur Agrawal, Souradeep Paul and Vishesh Gupta (all 2015 - B.Arch.), is one of the eight early-stage non-profit startups selected for an 18-month incubation program by the NS Raghavan Centre for Entrepreneurial Learning (NSRCEL) at the Indian Institute of Management (IIM) Bangalore. The founders will also receive fellowship support of 18 lakh.
This is part of India's first-ever, non-profit startup incubator supported by the Michael and Susan Dell Foundation. The selected organizations are tackling some of the toughest challenges in education and skills among poor communities around the country.
Anthill Creations aims to build sustainable playscapes for children by using recyclable materials. The idea of Anthill Creations is to create the world where communities come together and active play becomes affordable and accessible to all. It works towards lighter, quicker and cheaper transformation of dead zones into interactive and sustainable playscapes from scrap tyres and recycled material by mobilizing the communities. Recycling non-biodegradable material like tyres, therefore, would not just help safeguard the environment but be cost effective as a building material too.
“Traditionally, mass produced recreational equipment for building a playground would cost a minimum of Rs. 2 lakh, but since we are using material that is considered trash by some, we have been successful in setting up playgrounds for just Rs. 20,000,” Souradeep had said in an interview.

Like earlier years Placement Committee [Core Committee] will be formed to assist the Career Development Centre for better placements of students.

The students eligible are : 3rd year Dual Degree / 3rd Year Integrated M.Sc. / 1st Year M. Tech./ 1st year M.Sc.(2-year) students from all Departments / Centres / Schools.

NO applications will be accepted after the deadline under any circumstances.
While submitting the applications, the applicants should enter their name / roll number / with signature in a list available with the CDC.

Selections will be made based on a test of business communication skills followed by personal interviews. The detailed schedule is given below.

Application submission : 29th August 2017(TUESDAY) by 12.00 Noon to CDC Office
Selection Process : will be notified later

Looking forward for an active participation.

The CV module has been the center of much frustration during placements 2016. Things have drastically improved since, but several students still found the process painful and annoying. What was your experience like?

With an aim to teach students the basic life science techniques, IIT Kharagpur is going to start Genomics Laboratory that would be first of its kind in India. The primary objective of the laboratory would be to teach all the students at the second year the basic techniques of life sciences that would include microscopy-based observation, molecular biology, protein structure and function and lastly, bioinformatics. Under the mentorship of faculties, from third year onwards, students would be allowed to plan and execute experiments by their own. The lab and its equipment for research would be available for the students for 24×7.

In an unprecedented move, the Central government will provide Rs 70,000 as a monthly fellowship to those researchers doing their PhDs in IITs or IISc for a period of five years. At the 67th Foundation Day of IIT Kharagpur, Union higher education secretary Kewal Kumar Sharma said, “As part of the research fellowship scheme of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, we wish the meritorious students who are being forced to leave the country for purely financial reasons stay within the country. We will provide 2,000 such monthly fellowships across the IIT system and IISc Bengaluru. The cabinet nod for the proposal should come soon. We are hopeful to start it from the next session,”
Presently researcher-students get Rs 25,000 as monthly scholarship at IITs.

We believe that this will financially empower students having a keen interest in research to continue their work without being forced to opt for lucrative corporate jobs for higher pay.

Source: http://www.dnaindia.com/i...

IIT Kharagpur and Tata Medical Center have agreed on institutional collaboration in education, research and outreach programmes in the field of interdisciplinary medical research.

"Plans are underway for joint research programmes with external funding. Exchange programmes will be promoted through creation of visiting faculty, scientist positions with access to laboratory facilities for joint research and exchange of data," said Prof Suman Chakraborty, Mechanical Engineering faculty and programme coordinator from IIT Kharagpur.

As conveyed by Professor P.P. Chakrabarti, on the ocassion of the institute's 67th Foundation Day, IIT Kharagpur is gearing up to open a Centre of Excellence for research on Artificial Intelligence.

"Two Centres are being planned. One on AI research and one for extension of science and heritage part (the Sandhi science-culture initiative). Alumni is organising support for developing these two areas," IIT Kharagpur Director P.P. Chakrabarti said here during the institute's 67th Foundation Day.

"It will also get linked with the supercomputing facility, cloud computing etc. Additionally we want to do some really good projects in climate change and AI, big projects on healthcare and AI so that will require augmented funds," he said.

story: Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur added 5 new photos.
message:
In an initiative of its own kind, “Staff Excellency Awards” were awarded to some of the staff members in Azad Hall of Residence on the eve of Independence Day for their exemplary service. Amongst the awardees, one was the Mess Supervisor who has been discharging his duty with discipline and commitment for several years. Even though his daily official work starts around 5.30 am, he has seldom been late. Another, a mess worker who lives 25 kilometers away from the campus, works till late in the night to clean the plates and has seldom been absent.
In an another good gesture, plantation drive was also organized on this eve and wardens of the same hall planted trees in the hall premises to send out the message regarding the dire need of planting more and more trees.

"Everyone should learn how to program a computer, because it teaches you how to think." - Steve Jobs ;)

Like every other semester, let's once again dive into the world of learning something new. This time, KOSS brings to you its series of Python Classes, an effort to bring out the developer in you. Learn how to code in Python, by starting from the basics, and having a proper hands-on experience in building software. No prior experience in programming is required. As long as you are enthusiastic enough to learn, things will go smooth! ;)

Fill up this form [1], if you are interested in attending the classes. Everyone should have their laptops (fully charged, since providing power supply won't be possible), and have Python installed on them. You can download Python from here [2]. More resources will be mailed to you, once you have filled up the form.

See you all!

Venue: CS 120, CS Department
Time: 3:30 pm - 5:30 pm
Date: Saturday, 19th Aug

[1]: https://tinyurl.com/kossp...

[2]: https://www.python.org/do...

Wanted to know how much CGPA does it take to get your branch changed at the end of the first year? Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur brings to you an extensive analysis of the Department Change statistics for the batch of 2016-17. DepC is one of the major goals for the first years who don't get their desired branch on the basis of JEE rank. The analysis consists of CGPA cut off for different branches, the number of students outgoing and incoming to a particular branch, comparison of cut offs for the year 2016 and 2017.
A total of 110 students got their branch changed this year. As expected, the cut off was highest for CSE i.e., 9.73. Read the full analysis here:
http://awaaziitkgp.org/in...

Thirteen students from the Kharagpur RoboSoccer Students' Group (KRSSG) team represented the institute in the recently concluded RoboCup held in Nagoya (Japan). For qualification, they had submitted a video in the month of February and qualified for the final event.
RoboCup is an annual international robotics competition proposed and founded in 1997 with the aim of promoting robotics and AI research, by offering a publicly appealing, but formidable challenge. This year RoboCup was held in Nagoya, Japan. They participated in two leagues in RoboCup - Small Sized League and Humanoid Simulation League.
This year, it was their first participation in the Small Sized League and they faced a lot of technical difficulties. A total of twenty-four teams had qualified for the league, out of which only twenty could finally make it to the league. The twenty teams were divided into four groups. From each group, first two teams on the basis of performance were selected for the quarter finals. Unfortunately, they couldn’t make it to the quarters.
In the humanoid simulation league, it was their second participation. They stood 8th among 13 teams. They were able to defeat 5 different teams in one to one matches. They won a total of 7 matches, drew 3 and were in the quarter finals. They missed the chance to go to the semi finals by just one match!
Next year, the RoboCup will be held in Montreal, Canada. We hope for a better performance and even better results in the upcoming RoboCup.
Link to Competition website: https://www.robocup2017.o... /

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates the entire team for their stupendous efforts and commendable performance! They have surely made us all proud by putting IIT Kharagpur on RoboSoccer's world map.

(In the picture, Team KRSSG is with the Team Tigers Mannheim in Small Sized League Competition)

Pledge Taken at IIT Kharagpur on the occasion for celebration of 70 Years of Independence and 75 years of Quit India Movement. The event took place in a packed IIT Kharagpur Netaji Auditorium. IIT Kharagpur's history is intricately linked with the Independence Movement.

Hola Freshers!

We hope you have started to settle into the daily bustle of the campus. In the past week you might have been glued to the notice boards of your halls, or rather they would have been glued with posters introducing a multitude of different societies and groups. Every society puts up a great effort just to capture a part of that board space, to ultimately capture your eye and even more to sell themselves to you later on. Before any narcissism creeps in, we would like to point out the importance of the existence of this plethora of opportunities out there. For starters, the sheer number of these societies is what differentiates KGP from the rest of the IITs. Topping that, over time, each of these societies have turned into hubs of creativity, intellectual might, cutting-edge research, sources of valuable insights and more than anything else, a great place to make friends and forge bonds that last forever.

Hence we would like to bring to your notice a little project we did. Presenting the Periodic Table of KGPian Societies, an interactive compilation of all known societies in our campus so that you at least have a brief idea of what to expect in the coming days, make your choices wisely and play your cards right, both intellectually and socially.

https://thescholarsavenue...

P.S: Any societies that need any edits in their respective sections can ping us, or mail us (thescholarsavenue@ gmail.com ) with the edits.
We have only accounted groups that are open to all and are not limited by the Departments and we agree that we might have missed a few nevertheless.

Remember the announcement of getting the synthetic track built in Jnan Ghosh Stadium one and half years ago? Plans have been chalked out, the timeline has been rescheduled again and again, but we are yet to see even the first glimpse of any kind of construction work out there. In the series of articles under the column "Your Perspective", we would like to introduce you to the thoughts of a 5th year KGPian who feels that the delay in construction of synthetic track is dampening the spirit of athletes. And now that KGPians have performed brilliantly in sports fests and meets including the recent one in 67th West Bengal State Annual Athletics Meet, "IIT Kharagpur needs the synthetic track more now than ever!"

In case you wish to express your thoughts on a particular topic related to the campus, email them to awaazofiitkgp@ gmail.com with the subject as "Your Perspective".

Fourteen alumni of IIT Kharagpur were conferred with the Distinguished Alumnus Award at the 63rd Convocation for their outstanding achievements and contribution to their respective fields. They are:

1) Anuradha Acharya - M.Sc. Physics (1995), the founder and CEO of Mapmygenome (molecular diagnostic company), founder and ex-CEO of Ocimum Bio Solutions (genomics outsourcing company), awarded Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum in 2011.

2) Sanghamitra Bandyopadhyay - M.Tech. Computer Science and Engineering (1994), Director of the Indian Statistical Institute, computer scientist specializing in computational biology, Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize winner in Engineering Science (2010).

3) Sujit Banerji - B.Tech. Mechanical Engineering (1960), M.Tech. Industrial Engineering (1962), Professor of Operations Management at Warwick Manufacturing Group (University of Warwick), bestowed with Glory of India Award by the India International Friendship Society (2010).

4) Deepak Basu - B.Sc. Physics (1968) and B.Tech. Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering (1971), a social entrepreneur, founder and chairman of Anudeep Foundation, received NASSCOM Social Innovation Honors award in 2012.

5) Arun Kumar Bhaduri - B.Tech. (1983) and Ph.D. (1992) both in Metallurgical and Material Science Engineering, Director of Indira Gandhi Centre for Atomic Research, a distinguished scientist.

6) Subhasis Chaudhuri - B.Tech. Electronics and Electrical Communication (1985), leading expert in Image Processing and Computer Vision, professor at the department of Electrical Engineering at IIT Bombay, recipient of Dr. Vikram Sarabhai Research Award (2001) as well as Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize in Engineering Sciences (2004).

7) Raj Kamal Jha - B.Tech. Mechanical Engineering (1988), Chief Editor of The Indian Express, one of the finest journalist of India and internationally acclaimed novelist.

8) Surajit Kar Purkayastha - B.Tech. Mechanical Engineering (1978), an IPS officer and currently Director General of Police (DGP) of West Bengal.

9) Dr Brajendra Mishra - B.Tech. Metallurgical and Materials Engineering (1981), Kenneth G. Merriam Distinguished Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Assoc. Director of the Metal Processing Institute at the Worcester Polytechnic Institute, Director of the National Science Foundation’s Industry/University Collaborative Research Center on Resource Recovery & Recycling

10) RAdm Shekhar Mittal - M.Tech. Electronics and Electrical Communication Engineering (1985), current chairman and managing director of the defence PSU Goa Shipyard Limited, specialist in fleet maintenance, weapon engineering and the intricacies of surface and submarine design.

11) Aneesh Reddy - B.Tech. Mechanical Engineering (2006), Co-Founder & CEO at Capillary Technologies.

12) Anand Sen - B.Tech. Metallurgical Engineering (1981), ex-chief of Marketing & sales - Flat Products. current Vice President at Flat Products & TQM, awarded Essar Gold Medal by Indian Institute of Metals (2004).

13) Dr Ruma Acharya - M.Tech. Chemical Engineering (1973), an eminent Indian-American entrepreneur and philanthropist, founder of Grounded Technologies Inc.

14) Amitabha Ghosh - Msc. Geology and Geophysics (1993), Chairman, Science Operations Working Group -- Mission Operations at the NASA Mars Exploration Rover Mission, was the only Asian on NASA's Mars Pathfinder mission, recipient of NASA Mars Pathfinder Achievement Award in 1997 and the NASA Mars Exploration Rover Achievement Award in 2004.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates all of them and wishes them best for their future endeavours!

For the first time in the sports history of IIT Kharagpur, our team participated in the West Bengal State Sports Meet held in Salt Lake Stadium, Kolkata. In the 67th edition of State Sports Meet which was held on 29th June to 1st July, a team of 6 students represented IIT Kharagpur and performed remarkably well.
Abin Devassia finished fourth in Discus Throw with a heave of astounding 37.25 metres. He also had 11.68 metres to his name in Shot put. Dimple Kapadia clocked 14 seconds in 100 metres and jumped 4.16 metres in Long Jump. Utsav Mazumder clocked a brilliant 11.9 seconds in 100 metres. Sairam Alla, a seasoned campaigner, took a mere 23.6 seconds in 200 metres. The credit for this marvellous performance and beginning of a new chapter in KGP's sports history goes to the coach Mr. Pranab Sarkar as well.
Abin Devassia who hails from Wayanad (Kerala), a 3rd year student of Ocean Engineering and Naval Architecture, is associated with Discuss Throw as he prefers field events. With only a mere practice of 2 months, he has a record of throwing 37.22 metres which in itself is a great accomplishment.
Korabu Dimple Kapadia, a student of Agriculture and Food Engineering, is a 100 metres sprinter. Hailing from Vizag, she comes from a family which has been associated with sports. This 3rd year student has been associated with sports from a tender age of 5.
Utsav Mazumdar, a student of Agriculture and Food Engineering, who hails from Jamshedpur is a 100 metres sprinter.
Sairam Alla, a 5th year student of Computer Science and Engineering, hails from Vizag and primarily takes part in 200 m and 400 m.

A team of students from IIT Kharagpur, headed by Prof. Aurobinda Routray at the Department of Electrical Engineering, have created a device named Smart Hygiene Monitor (SHM) that helps in reducing the use of water, harmful cleaning agents and even manpower by alerting authorities about the need to clean an area (toilets, eateries, hospitals, parks, airports, railway stations) only when needed.
The Smart Hygiene Monitor (SHM) records levels of ammonia, sulphur dioxide, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, volatile organic compounds and particulate matter through sensors and sends online alerts to stakeholders when a certain threshold is crossed. It can be installed at any place where cleanliness needs to be monitored at regular intervals. At present, these public facilities are generally cleaned at fixed intervals, irrespective of how dirty they are.
The device has been developed using an embedded platform incorporated with sensors that are connected via the Internet of Things (IoT). “This monitor using sensors detects the level of hygiene in a room and through cloud sends data to the stakeholders,” Prof. Routray said, adding that the setup cost for a 20-sq ft area would be less than Rs 5,000.

Source: http://m.economictimes.co...

The number of seats (to be filled through JEE counselling) lying vacant in IITs this year is highest in the last four years. Out of the total 10,962 available seats in 23 IITs, 121 remained vacant after completion of the counselling for admission, minister of state for human resource development Mahendra Nath Pandey told the Rajya Sabha today in a written reply.
IIT BHU has the maximum number of empty (32), followed by IIT (ISM) Dhanbad (23), IIT Jammu (13) and IIT Kharagpur (9). One seat each is vacant at IIT Bombay, IIT Madras, IIT Ropar, IIT Palakkad and IIT Goa.
The last round of counselling was held on July 19. All the IITs were supposed to complete admissions by July 25.

As per the recent data released by MHRD, 889 students have dropped out of IITs in the academic year of 2016-17. Out of these, 630 were Post Graduate students, 196 were PhD scholars and 63 were undergraduates. There has been a 35% rise in the number of dropouts as compared to previous year.
“The main reason for PhD and postgraduate students leaving courses midway are offers for placement in public sector enterprises and personal preference for better opportunities elsewhere”, as stated by the MHRD. Also, some undergraduates left due to their poor performances as well.
Another reason given by the MHRD for students dropping out mid way was the shortage of faculty. As of now, 4,500 seats (38%) remain vacant out of 13,012 seats. To address the problem, the ministry has decided to allow faculty working under central autonomous bodies to join IITs.
Interestingly, the recently set up IITs in Tirupati, Bhilai, Goa, Dharwad, Jammu and Dhanbad (formerly Indian School of Mines) have seen no dropouts. Most dropouts were from IIT-Roorkee (27%), followed by Delhi (20.6%), Kanpur (17.4%) and Kharagpur (10.6%).

“Every student in technical institute should undergo three internships each spanning four to eight weeks before completion of his/her under-graduation course. The responsibility will be on the institute to help students find a suitable industry for the internship,” Union HRD minister Javadekar was quoted as telling the Lok Sabha on Monday. The responsibility will be on the institute to help students find a suitable industry for the internship.
His statements come in the context of AICTE data from 2015-2016 which asserted that in 10,328 technical institutes, only 6.96 lakh students got campus placements out of 15.87 lakh students.
Meanwhile, the teachers of engineering institutes will have to take up online courses offered on government’s SWAYAM portal. “Every teacher in each of the technical discipline shall mandatorily undergo an annual refresher course through SWAYAM portal (Massive open online course), encapsulating all advances in their field of study,” the minister said.
However, it'll be interesting to see when are these decisions going to get formulated and transformed into action. This, if implemented, is surely expected to cause a huge turnaround in the field of engineering education.

Students of IIT Kharagpur have come up with innovative ideas in the past and present which have been able to make a positive impact in the society. The Entrepreneurial ventures of students have a diversified range which generally come with an efficacious way to help out people and foster the culture of innovation.

Prazium, by Enactus, IIT Kharagpur is one such Entrepreneurial action, which has won the 6th edition of the Saint Gobain Scholarship of Rs.1,00,000 for it's initial development, which was supported by Ethos so as to find a solution to the structural design problems faced today, using sustainable and eco-friendly methods. Hitesh Vyas, a 4th year architecture student, as one of the members of Enactus, presented the project in the National level competition held in May 2017 which was declared the winner of the scholarship. It tends to reduce the cost of construction and develop houses by using processed Bamboo as a replacement for steel reinforcements.
Professor Damodar Maity of the Civil Engineering Department of IIT Kharagpur helped with the background research for this development.

Prazium is an indigenous project in collaboration with the concrete laboratories at IIT Kharagpur and some of the prototypes have been practiced in the IIT Kharagpur’s campus itself. It now aims to provide the new development to the nearby rural areas to the campus and eventually expand throughout the country.

The Scholars’ Avenue congratulates the Prazium team for their achievement and wishes them the best of luck for their future endeavors.

According to a recent report by Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India for the year ended March 2016, avoidable expenses and irregularities at some of the IITs have cost Rs. 18.03 crores. In this Compliance Audit Observations report, these are some of the few points made about these irregularities:
1) Idle expenditure: Failure on the part of the IIT Roorkee to construct sewer line across NH-58 and STP at Roorkee and Saharanpur campuses resulted in an idle expenditure of Rs. 15.06 crore incurred on the construction of sewer line which could not be utilised even after the lapse of more than four years from the scheduled date of completion.

2) Irregular payment of Service Tax: IIT Roorkee made payment of service tax amounting to Rs. 1.34 crores on the outsourced services, although these services were exempted from payment of such tax. Same goes for IIT Patna with Rs. 8.36 crores.

3) Avoidable expenditure towards penal charges on electricity consumption: IIT Madras had incurred an avoidable expenditure of Rs. 1.05 crores towards penalty for exceeding contracted demand during April 2013 to March 2016 due to non-review and enhancement of sanctioned demand.

4) Irregular waiver of overpayment: The Board of Governors of IIT Jodhpur irregularly waived recovery of excess payment amounting to Rs. 59.38 lakhs made to its faculty, which is now under recovery at the instance of Audit.

5) Irregular reimbursement of LTC (Leave Travel Concession) claims by Central Autonomous Bodies: Central Autonomous Bodies irregularly reimbursed air fares of Rs. 6.90 crores during 2012-16 against the air tickets purchased by their employees from unauthorised agents in violation of the MoF guidelines for availing Leave Travel Concession. IIT Kharagpur, despite delayed submission of claims, did not recover LTC advance of Rs. 1.14 crore of which Rs. 19.85 lakh was to be forfeited. Cross verification of claims with the Airlines also revealed that the air fares reimbursed by the IIT Kharagpur and IIT Bombay were inflated by Rs. 18.56 lakhs (11.21 lakhs for IIT Kharagpur, 7.35 lakhs for IIT Bombay).

CAG Audit Report Source: http://www.cag.gov.in/sit...

"If there were ever to be another Ajit and you could swap me for him, don't hesitate. Make the trade!", said Warren Buffett, chairman of the board, about Ajit Jain in a letter to Berkshire shareholders in 2016.
Ajit Jain, an IIT Kharagpur alumnus, President of Berkshire Hathaway Insurance group and one of the two potential successors to legendary investor Warren Buffett has donated stocks of the company to IITKGP USA Foundation for his alma mater IIT Kharagpur. Jain is touted to be one of the two favoured candidates as eventual successor of Berkshire Hathaway founder and CEO Buffett.
Ajit Jain, a distinguished alumnus of IIT Kharagpur, graduated with B.Tech. in Mechanical Engineering in the year 1972. In 1978, he moved to the United States, where he earned an MBA from Harvard University. After graduation, he held various positions at top tier management consultancy McKinsey & Co., up until 1986 when he joined Berkshire Hathaway. He is currently the President of Berkshire Hathaway Insurance group and leads several other insurance companies housed inside the broader Berkshire Group.
It's quite a unique gesture as the institute has been receiving only monetary donations till now. “Ajit is very close and dear to Warren Buffett. Warren considers him like his own son. We are proud to have our alumni so valuable to Warren Buffett,” said Mr. Vinod Gupta, another famous distinguished alumnus who pioneered big-ticket alumni contributions to IIT Kharagpur with a $2 million-plus donation in the Nineties.

Source: https://www.telegraphindi...

Students of IIT Kharagpur have again made us all proud with their stupendous performance in Qualcomm Innovation Fellowship (QInF) program, 2017. Three out of six winners are from IIT Kharagpur and the other three includes one team each from IIT Bombay, IIIT Hyderabad and IIsc Bangalore. These six winning teams will receive a financial award of INR 10 lakhs (approx. $15,000) each for the academic year 2017-18 and mentorship from Qualcomm engineers. This program recognises, rewards and mentors innovative graduate students across a broad range of technical research.
The winning teams from IIT Kharagpur are:
1) Avisek Lahiri and Abhinav Agarwalla from The Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, recommended by Prof. Prabir Kumar Biswas and Prof. Pabitra Mitra for their proposal on “Domain adversarial networks for bridging cross domain semantic gaps in computer vision”.
2) Sayandeep Saha and Sikhar Patranabis from The Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, recommended by Prof. Debdeep Mukhopadhyay and Prof. Pallab Dasgupta for their proposal on “Automating fault based cryptanalysis in secure embedded applications using machine learning”.
3) Preety Priya and Sucharita Chakraborty from The Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, recommended by Prof. Debarati Sen for their proposal on “Blind joint equalization and detection in presence of non-linearity and synchronization errors for millimeter wave communications”.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates the winners and wishes them all the best for their future endeavours.

Source: https://www.qualcomm.com/...

|| QS World Rankings ||
QS World University Rankings, one of the most trusted rankings around the world, are out! MIT, Stanford and Harvard University have bagged first three positions respectively. Among Indian institutions, IIT Delhi tops the list with a world rank of 172. Just behind IIT Delhi, IIT Bombay and IISc Bangalore are there with ranks of 179 and 190, respectively. This is the first time that three Indian institutions have made it to top 200 in this list. IIT Kharagpur has improved its rank as compared to previous year and bagged a world rank of 308. The parameters that are taken into consideration for the rankings include academic reputation, employer reputation, student faculty ratio, citations per faculty, international faculty, international students etc.

IIT Kharagpur ranks 3rd in the number of selections in Google Summer of Code, 2017 program with 31 selections. This is a jump of 4 positions from the 7th rank in 2016. Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur congratulates the student community and wishes that the open-source culture keep flourishing in the campus!
https://opensource.google...

Google Summer of Code statistics are out, and we are glad to announce that we had a whopping 31 selections from IIT Kharagpur this year, which is more than double of last year.

Worldwide, IIT KGP stands 3rd in the list of number of students getting selected, after IIIT Hyderabad (39) and BITS Pilani (37).

Moreover, India stands undefeated among having the total number of students getting selected, since last 5 years. This year, India had 569 of its applications getting selected, with US standing second (126 selections).

This clearly shows the growing trend of Open-Source development, and we strive to bring and involve more number of people into Open Source :)

For more information, visit the blog.

The Scholars' Avenue would like to bring notice to its readers about a Quantitative Research Summer Training Program that is being offered by WorldQuant from 1st June to 31st July, 2017. You can take a look at the details of the training below:

WorldQuant Summer Training Program

Based on the success of last year’s Quantitative Research Summer Training Program, we would like to invite applicants for the 2017 program.
Our program offers distinctive hands-on experience in developing mathematical or quantitative models using our web-based stock simulation platform (Websim). With over 1300 registrations, 62 students across various schools in India qualified for the 2016 Summer Training Program to become Research Consultants with WorldQuant.

Our Summer Training Program is designed to offer insight into the quantitative model building space. The virtual training program is a unique learning opportunity within the investment management industry. It is a tailored program that combines virtual training and workshop sessions in developing alphas/trading models.
If you show potential and demonstrate exceptional performance during your time with us, you may be offered a part-time Research Consultant position with us.

Below are a few key highlights of the Summer Training Program:
Ø Regular online training sessions;

Ø Mentoring and guidance from experienced quantitative researchers;

Ø Eligible participants have the potential of being considered for a Research Consultant opportunity at the end of program, which may include aone-time special stipend of up to 1,00,000 INR;

Ø Certificate from WorldQuant.

Participation Requirements:

Hold or working towards Bachelor’s degree or Master’s degree in Engineering, Science, Mathematics, Finance or any other related field that ishighly analytical and quantitative
1st and 2nd year students will be given preference
Have a strong interest in learning about worldwide financial markets
Submit applications to your placement team
Register for a Websim account [ https://websim.worldquant... ] If you have already expressed interest through your institution’s placement office, please make sure you sign up for an account using the same email address. Please fill out your academic profile when applying for a new account.
On Websim, when prompted, please confirm your interest in being considered for the Summer Training Program.
Space in the program is limited, so selection of candidates for the program will be based on the applicant’s activity in Websim and academic achievement among other factors.

Training Program Completion:
Trainees who attend all scheduled training sessions, complete assignments and build a score on Websim based on the alphas they submit will receive a completion certificate at the end of the training program.
In addition, we may offer Research Consultant positions to candidates who complete the training successfully, and a one-time special stipend maybe awarded to outstanding performers upon becoming a Research Consultant.
Research Consultant offers are at our sole discretion and are subject to a background check and other applicable eligibility requirements.

JEE Main, JEE Advanced, BITSAT and other engineering entrance exams have taken place and few of them already have their results out. Rest of the results will also be out in a couple of weeks. Now that ranks of various entrance exams are out (or will be out), its equally important for the aspirants to get acquainted with all the required information and only then choose their branch and college. For that, there is a need of such a platform for proper counselling where aspirants can get information and advice, so that they can make better decisions. To serve this purpose, Student Welfare Group (SWG) IIT Kharagpur has taken an initiative and formed a JEE Counselling group (link below). All the aspirants looking for joining college this year as well as students who are already in colleges and hence, can help out aspirants with their experiences, are requested to join this group.
https://www.facebook.com/...

Two of our students Sahashranshu Maurya and Somrup Chakraborty have been selected to represent our institute on the international stage this year, through their team TAKNIQUEE, which has been shortlisted for the finals of the Shell Ideas 360 2016/2017, a student collaborative programme which features in the list of top ten student competitions in the world. The winner would be chosen through a voting platform, called the Audience Choice Awards.
TAKNIQUEE from IIT KGP has come up with an innovative approach to tackle the energy problem and achieve cooling in the midst of summers using an energy-friendly approach. The name of their idea is "Passive Solar Water Wall".
They will be fighting it out for the maximum number of votes with 4 other universities, namely, Nanyang Technological University (Singapore), Delft University of Technology (Netherlands), University of Texas at Austin (USA) and University of Cambridge (UK), who themselves have put forth new ways to tip the energy scale.

You can showcase your support to the team by voting for the team at the link provided below. The voting will close on the 23rd of May and the results will be announced on the 25th of May. The team will be on it's way to London on the 24th of May to give a final presentation.

For more details about the teams and their ideas, as well as for voting for our team, please visit

http://www.shellideas360....

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the team and wishes it all the best for the finals.

No CFC emission, no carbon emission, negligible electricity usage and almost 50% reduction in the cooling cost, have we ever thought of such type of air conditioning system in our house? Well never! But, two talented minds of IIT Kharagpur, Sahashranshu Maurya and Somrup Chakraborty(Department of Geology and Geophysics), have come up with a unique idea to challenge the climate change, global warming and many other environmental issues (listen the full idea here: https://vimeo.com/2122331... ).
This year in Shell Ideas360, over 17000 students collaborated to share over 750 innovative ideas to tackle the pressures on the world’s energy, water and food resources. Through the various stages and rigrous selection process finally five ideas have been shortlisted for Audience Choice Award at #makethefuture Live in London. Passive Solar Water Wall, by team "Takniquee" from Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, is one of the five ideas shortlisted.
The team with the highest number of votes will receive the Audience Choice Award 2016-17. The voting period is from May 13 to May 23, 2017. We request to every students of IIT Kharagpur to vote in a large number to support the team "Takniquee" and make them win the contest by large margin.
Cast your vote here: shellideas360.com/audienc...

Update on the Tragic Accident.

The primary investigation of the accident by the Andhra Pradesh Police which today shook the entire KGP family unfolded the identification of the deceased and the cause of the accident. The bereaved N Ravi Teja, 27, a Software Engineer at Oracle, Hyderabad, T Rohith, 28, a Software Development Engineer at Amazon, Hyderabad and P Surya Teja, 27, Principal Software Engineer at ZeMoSo Technologies, Hyderabad all belonged to the 2011 batch of IIT Kharagpur.
Surya Teja who was at the steering of the Hyundai Verna, tried to overtake a DCM van from the left side with the car believed to be speeding at about 120 kmph rammed into the side railing after clashing with the van, said P Laxmikanth Reddy, senior inspector, Andhra Pradesh Police. He further added that the driver of the van cannot be blamed as he was driving in the the third lane of the four lane Ring Road at a speed less than 80 kmph which is legitimate. Although a case has been registered under sections 304-A and 337 of the Indian Penal Code against the van driver who himself is undergoing treatment for his head injuries. The police also said that none of the youngsters were wearing seat belt.

Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur urges everyone to carefully follow the traffic rules with full security and safety measures while travelling to avert such untoward happenings.

With inputs from Deccan Chronicle and The New Indian Express.

We are very sorry to inform you that 4 Alumni of IIT KGP met with an accident in Hyderabad today morning at 7:40, out of which 3 succumbed to death. All of them were graduates working in different IT firms. They were to attend a marriage when they met with this fatal mishap after being grazed by a truck. Ravi Teja and Surya Teja died on the spot, while Rohit breathed his last during the treatment.

We offer condolences to their families, and pray with all our hearts that this unfortunate trend of deaths in/related to our institute does not continue any further.

http://www.newindianexpre...

In what came as a shock to the institute, three graduates of IIT Kharagpur, Ravi Teja, Surya Teja and Rohith lost their life in a road mishap on Outer Ring Road at Tukkuguda on the outskirts of Hyderabad yesterday. They were travelling by a car from Gachibowli to Khammam to attend a marriage when the vehicle was grazed by a truck coming from opposite direction. The car swerved, hit side-railing of the road and overturned killing Ravi and Surya on the spot while Rohith succumbed to head injuries at a nearby hospital.

Our heart goes with the family and friends of the deceased and may the departed souls rest in peace.

story: Metakgp with Abhishek Tripathi and 2 others.
message:
We are organising the second "MetaKGP Talks" on April 13th (7PM-8PM) at Maggu Room(F127, Main Building). There will be two talks:
1. Ashris Choudhury and Ankita Diwan (Final year B.Arch):
Speaking on “Building future together : Artists and Engineers”. The talk explores the messy process of creativity shedding light on how innovation is a blend of analysis and synthesis. Ashris and Ankita talk about the importance of collaboration and discussion between the engineers and artists to make innovation happen fluidly.
2. Abhishek Tripathi (Member at TLS):
Speaking on “Poetry, Collaboration and People - Sublimation of knowledge by doing and seeing”. The talk would be related to Abhishek's experience of learning from people, literature and history.
We hope to see you there with your friends!

3. Ayush Goyal : loses to Naresh R by 18–10, loses to Nishant Nikhil by 14–13
4. Arun Patro : loses to Naresh R by 18–7, loses to Ayush Goyal by 16–11
5. Pranit Bauva : loses to Naresh R by 20–6, loses to Arun Patro by 15–12
6. Rameshwar Bhaskaran : loses to Naresh R by 22–3, loses to Pranit Bauva by 18–8
7. Sayan Sinha : loses to Naresh R by 22–3, loses to Rameshwar Bhaskaran by 14–9

29 out of 126 eligible voters casted their votes. The top three candidates,
Naresh R, Nishant Nikhil and Ayush Goyal will be maintainers of metakgp for
next one year, eight months and four months respectively.

Congratulations to new maintainers, we hope that metakgp will reach new heights under their leadership. Thanks a lot to all candidates who took out their precious time to participate in the election process.

BTW as a reminder to everyone, not being a maintainer doesn't stop you from taking initiatives. Metakgp is an open community, you can start your own projects, improve existing ones and make metakgp more awesome.

Please submit any (anonymous) feedback you might have about the election using this form https://docs.google.com/f...
and of course if you want to discuss something or just hangout with us, you can join us on our slack channel http://metakgp-slack.hero... /

story: Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS added 23 new photos to the album: GSoC Intro Seminar 2017 — with Anchit Navelkar and 6 others at Vikramshila, IIT Kharagpur.
message: We had successfully conducted an introductory workshop on GSoC wherein we had invited speakers who were selected as students as well as mentors in GSoC. They shared their experiences, benefits, tips and advice on how to participate in the open source culture! Thanks to all of the speakers (Pranit Bauva, Himanshu Mishra, Avijit Ghosh, Nishant Nikhil, Sampad Saha, Anchit Navelkar, Shivam Vats, Ayush Pandey, Harsh Gupta, Pranay Yadav, Abinash Meher) as well as those who attended!

Greetings !

We are sharing the highlights from the GSoC session yesterday for those who could not attend. This[1] is the link of our presentation.

Please join Klug on Slack[2] by inviting your self from here - https://klug-slack.heroku...
Join the #gsoc channel and introduce yourself in a line or two. You can find a lot of GSoCers from KGP[3] over there, so don't hesitate.

We had mentioned about FLOSS Manuals[4] for the students. You must give this a read. It is written in a very simple and lucid manner and is one of the most useful resources for you right now.

You should also give a light read to a classic article on How to Ask Smart Questions[5]. And this is not just for GSoC !

And finally, here are a bunch of resources for you to learn Git[6], which you would be using later.

Email us or ask on KLUG slack for any help that we can provide. Do not hesitate. :)

[1] https://docs.google.com/p...
[2] https://klug.slack.com
[3] https://wiki.metakgp.org/...
[4] http://write.flossmanuals...
[5] http://www.catb.org/~esr/...
[6] https://docs.google.com/d...

Cheers !

story: Kharagpur Open Source Society - KOSS added an event.
message:
Yes, it is that time of the year again when you have to convert coffee to code. I hope you all know that Google Summer of Code is approaching soon and the Selected Organization list is going to be published on coming Monday.
Therefore, we are planning to conduct a seminar on how to overcome the initial barrier and we will also provide you a lot of insights about GSoC program by people who have cracked GSoC before as students and as mentors. The mentors will provide you even better insights of how they select students and much more stuff.
Thus we hope to see you for the GSoC seminar on Monday, 27th February 2017 at 6.30pm Vikramshila V4.
Cheers!
Date: 06:30PM
Time: 27-02-2017
Veunu: Vikramshila, IIT Kharagpur

Yes, it is that time of the year again when you have to convert coffee to code. I hope you all know that Google Summer of Code is approaching soon and the Selected Organization list is going to be published on coming Monday.

Therefore, we are planning to conduct a seminar on how to overcome the initial barrier and we will also provide you a lot of insights about GSoC program by people who have cracked GSoC before as students and as mentors. Thus we hope to see you for the GSoC seminar on Monday, 27th February 2017 at 6.30pm Vikramshila V4.

Cheers!
